messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Distributed Algorithms for Covering, Packing and Maximum Weighted Matching

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper gives poly-logarithmic-round, distributed Œ¥ùõø\delta-approximation algorithms for covering problems with submodular cost and monotone covering constraints (Submodular-cost Covering). The approximation ratio Œ¥ùõø\delta is the maximum number of variables in any constraint. Special cases include Covering Mixed Integer Linear Programs (CMIP), and Weighted Vertex Cover (with Œ¥=2ùõø2\delta=2). Via duality, the paper also gives poly-logarithmic-round, distributed Œ¥ùõø\delta-approximation algorithms for Fractional Packing linear programs (where Œ¥ùõø\delta is the maximum number of constraints in which any variable occurs), and for Max Weighted c-Matching in hypergraphs (where Œ¥ùõø\delta is the maximum size of any of the hyperedges; for graphs Œ¥=2ùõø2\delta=2). The paper also gives parallel (RNC) 2-approxi-mation algorithms for CMIP with two variables per constraint and Weighted Vertex Cover. The algorithms are randomized. All of the approximation ratios exactly match those of comparable centralized algorithms.111Preliminary versions appeared in Koufogiannakis09DistributedCovering ; Koufogiannakis09DistributedPacking . Work by the first author was partially supported by the Greek State Scholarship Foundation (IKY). Work by the second author was partially supported by NSF awards CNS-0626912, CCF-0729071.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Low-diameter graph decomposition is in NC",
        "On k-column sparse packing programs",
        "Local ratio: a unified framework for approximation algorithms",
        "A linear-time approximation algorithm for the weighted vertex cover problem",
        "A local-ratio theorem for approximating the weighted vertex cover problem",
        "On the equivalence between the primal-dual schema and the local-ratio technique",
        "Rounding algorithms for covering problems",
        "Strengthening integrality gaps for capacitated network design and covering problems",
        "A fast and efficient nc algorithm for maximal matching",
        "A greedy heuristic for the set-covering problem",
        "A fast distributed algorithm for approximating the maximum matching",
        "Distributed packing in planar graphs",
        "Paths, trees, and flowers",
        "Matching: A well-solved class of integer linear programs",
        "Distributed weighted vertex cover via maximal matchings",
        "Primal-dual based distributed algorithms for vertex cover with semi-hard capacities",
        "A primal-dual bicriteria distributed algorithm for capacitated vertex cover",
        "A fast approximation algorithm for the multicovering problem",
        "On the distributed complexity of computing maximal matchings",
        "Efficient bounds for the stable set, vertex cover, and set packing problems",
        "Approximation algorithms for the set covering and vertex cover problems",
        "Simple distributed weighted matchings",
        "Approximating weighted matchings in parallel",
        "A fast and simple randomized parallel algorithm for maximal matching",
        "An efficient distributed algorithm for constructing small dominating sets",
        "Approximation algorithms for combinatorial problems",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "Probabilistic recurrence relations",
        "An optimal parallel algorithm for maximal matching",
        "A primal-dual parallel approximation technique applied to weighted set and vertex covers",
        "Approximation algorithms for covering/packing integer programs",
        "Beating simplex for fractional packing and covering linear programs",
        "Distributed and parallel algorithms for weighted vertex cover and other covering problems",
        "Distributed fractional packing and maximum weighted b-matching via tail-recursive duality",
        "Greedy ŒîŒî\\Delta-approximation algorithm for covering with arbitrary constraints and submodular cost",
        "Distributed approximation of capacitated dominating sets",
        "What cannot be computed locally!",
        "The price of being near-sighted",
        "Constant-time distributed dominating set approximation",
        "What can be approximated locally?: case study: dominating sets in planar graphs",
        "Locality in distributed graph algorithms",
        "Low diameter graph decompositions",
        "Improved distributed approximate matching",
        "Distributed approximate matching",
        "On the ratio of optimal integral and fractional covers",
        "A simple parallel algorithm for the maximal independent set problem",
        "Implementing weighted b-matching algorithms: Towards a flexible software design",
        "What can be computed locally?",
        "Local, distributed weighted matching on general and wireless topologies",
        "Some simple distributed algorithms for sparse networks",
        "On the complexity of distributed network decomposition",
        "Fast primal-dual distributed algorithms for scheduling and matching problems",
        "Distributed computing: a locality-sensitive approach",
        "Approximability of sparse integer programs",
        "Improved approximation guarantees for packing and covering integer programs",
        "New approaches to covering and packing problems",
        "Parallel approximation algorithms for maximum weighted matching in general graphs",
        "Distributed weighted matching"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Distributed Algorithms for Covering, Packing and Maximum Weighted Matching, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
